modules.description: This module creates 2D and 3D line plots from sequences of coordinates, supporting optional styling, legends, point markers, and error bars. It operates on data types representing 1D, 2D, and 3D real-valued points, and constructs plot specifications consumable by the Gnuplot interface. Concrete use cases include visualizing time series data in 2D, plotting 3D trajectories, and displaying error margins in experimental data.

Defines and constructs colors for plots using RGB values or predefined constants like red, blue, green, and black. Supports specifying custom colors with floating-point red, green, and blue components. Used to set line or fill colors in visualizations generated through the Gnuplot interface.

This module defines and manipulates plotting styles for visualizing data points and shapes. It supports operations to set point types, sizes, colors, and circle-based markers with optional fill properties. Concrete use cases include customizing scatter plots with colored points or annotated diagrams using outlined or filled circles.

This module defines a range with optional minimum and maximum float bounds, used to specify axis limits in plots. It provides functions to create custom ranges and a default range with unspecified bounds. Concrete use cases include setting x and y axis limits when configuring plots in the Gnuplot interface.

This module defines and manipulates fill styles for shapes in Gnuplot plots. It supports operations to set fill styles to empty, solid with specified density and transparency, or patterned with a Gnuplot pattern code and transparency. These styles are applied to shapes drawn in plots, such as bars, polygons, or filled curves, to control their visual appearance.

This module creates 2D histograms from one-dimensional data points. It supports customization of bin count, bin width, color, and legend. Use it to visualize distributions of numerical data samples in plots.

This module defines a set of point type values used to specify marker styles in plots. It includes constants for common shapes like dots, squares, circles, and stars, as well as specialized markers such as delta and disk. These values are directly used to customize the appearance of data points in Gnuplot visualizations.

Handles dataset creation from sequences, arrays, or lists, converting these structures into a typed dataset representation. Works with any dimensionality, supporting data import for plotting. Use to prepare numerical data from common OCaml collections for visualization.

This module plots circles in 2D or 3D space from coordinate and radius data. It operates on tuples of type `r3` (for 2D: x, y, r) or `r4` (for 3D: x, y, z, r) within `Plot.Data.t` collections. Use it to visualize circular markers with variable radii, such as plotting 2D scatter plots with size-varying points or 3D spatial data with radial indicators.

This module creates 2D and 3D scatter plots from point data in `Plot.r2` and `Plot.r3` formats, supporting optional styling and legends. It allows specification of point appearance through `Plot.Style.t` and can display error bars in 2D plots. Concrete use cases include visualizing statistical data distributions, experimental results, and multi-dimensional datasets directly in Gnuplot.

This module configures axis tic marks for plots, controlling their placement, orientation, and visual properties. It operates on a `t` type that represents tic settings, allowing adjustments like setting borders, mirroring, rotation, and log scale. Concrete use cases include customizing x-axis tics to rotate labels for readability or defining fixed tic intervals for precise plot annotations.

Plots bar charts from labeled numerical data, supporting customizable fill styles, bar widths, and legends. Works with tuples of labels and numeric values to create 2D bar visualizations. Useful for comparing categorical data values in reports or analysis outputs.

This module enables creating and rendering 2D/3D visualizations like scatter plots, histograms, and bar charts using Gnuplot, with support for data representations such as `r3` (2D circles with radii) and `r4` (3D spheres). It offers styling controls for colors, point types, and fill patterns, along with axis configuration for ranges and tics to customize plot layout. Typical use cases include scientific data analysis, generating publication-quality plots in formats like PDF/PNG, or interactive visualization via Qt/X11 displays.
